title: dev.periods fails to process some/multiple transactions
body:
**System information**

```
Geth version:
Geth
Version: 1.8.17-stable
Git Commit: 8bbe720
Architecture: amd64
Protocol Versions: [63 62]
Network Id: 1
Go Version: go1.10
Operating System: linux
GOPATH=
GOROOT=/usr/lib/go-1.10
OS & Version: Linux Ubuntu 16.04
```
#### Expected behaviour

Should auto mine in case of multiple transactions also

#### Actual behavior

Not work for multiple transaction some time. It works for single transaction.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

`-dev.period value Block period to use in developer mode (0 = mine only if transaction pending) (default: 0)`

I used this command in my geth and auto mines the transaction. When I do one transaction like transfer then it works fine but when I do multiple transactions at once means bulk transfer sequentially then it fails in some cases. I need to manually start miner.start(1) at some point.

If you are using some scripts then please point me to that script or code.
How do you send 'concurrent transactions in a row'? Do you first generate and later send, or use sendTransaction() - like my script?

No, first I create an array for transactions to be mined. which consists of recipient and amount to transfer.
Then, I call **myContract.methods.transfer(to, amount).send()** to send token to the recipient with for loop.

From `geth`'s perspective, a transaction is a single signed transaction from an EOA. It may, in the case of ERC20 multi-send, cause several internal calls which causes ERC20 token movements, but as far as geth knows, it's still just a transaction. 

So, with that in mind, could you elaborate on

- Are you doing several _transactions_ or having problem with single transactions (containing multiple ERC20-sends)?
- What do you mean by "fails in some cases". Do you see any error message, either in the geth console or in the jsonrpc response message? Are the _transactions_ failing or the internal ERC20-transfers failing? 
- Is the for-loop an on-chain for-loop within `myContract` or are you also looping on the javascript side?

> Are you doing several transactions or having problem with single transactions (containing multiple ERC20-sends)?

**When doing multiple transactions.**

> What do you mean by "fails in some cases". Do you see any error message, either in the geth console or in the jsonrpc response message? Are the transactions failing or the internal ERC20-transfers failing?

**I didn't got any error messages. When transaction got submitted then, geth doesn't get mine that submitted the transaction. It remains in pending transactions. I could check that by eth.pendingTransactions.**

> Is the for-loop an on-chain for-loop within myContract or are you also looping on the javascript side?

**I am using it javascript side.**

can you point me to the code of dev-periods?

You should not need to use any such script. It should "just work" with `--dev`, without having to resort to any javascript-magic like that.

Actually, I would guess that it's the script that causes the mining to stop, and then there might be a race between pending-notifications that may or may not start it again. So I think the cause is not geth, but the script above.

In `--dev` mode, Geth automatically starts and stops the miner. If you have an extra script that also messes with the miner, it might very well be a race that causes the hang. @princesinha19 could you try without any script, just simply Geth in `--dev` mode?

right, @karalabe. Initially, I used dev-periods without any extra script. It was working properly for 1-2 transactions but when I requested bulk transfer then it got failed. Then, I used this script and started geth in normal mode after getting out from **--dev mode**.
I didn't merge both dev and script @holiman.
Ok, ignore the script -- we don't want to investigate an error in some random js script. Let's concentrate on the error, if there is one, with --dev.
yes, right @holiman. I think we should improve --dev.period so, that bulk transfer of ERC20 can succeed.
Great. So can you help me reproduce the error you're getting? If you show me the exact scripts and invocations, we can go from there

I tried reproing this with a bash script, to get some more paralellism in
```bash
account=$(curl -X POST  -H "Content-Type: application/json"  --data '{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"eth_coinbase","params":[],"id":1}' http://localhost:8545 | jq .result)

for i in {1..64}; do
        data="{\"jsonrpc\":\"2.0\",\"method\":\"eth_sendTransaction\",\"params\":[{\"from\": $account, \"to\": $account, \"value\":\"0x1\"}],\"id\":$i}"
        curl -X POST   -H "Content-Type: application/json" --data "$data" http://localhost:8545 &
done

sleep 3
curl -X POST  -H "Content-Type: application/json"  --data '{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"eth_pendingTransactions","params":[],"id":1}' http://localhost:8545 | jq .result
curl -X POST  -H "Content-Type: application/json"  --data "{\"jsonrpc\":\"2.0\",\"method\":\"eth_getTransactionCount\",\"params\":[$account,\"latest\"],\"id\":1}" http://localhost:8545 | jq .result
```
Running geth with `build/bin/geth --dev --rpc`. I get _zero_ drops, against master. If larger numbers of transactions are used, they will be dropped, since a too-far-off nonce gap will cause drops -- but those would not be present in `pending` later. 

Could you try running geth with `--verbosity 6` and paste the logs after you hit the error?
Okay @holiman. I will try and let you know.

This issue has been automatically closed because there has been no response to our request for more information from the original author. With only the information that is currently in the issue, we don't have enough information to take action. Please reach out if you have more relevant information or answers to our questions so that we can investigate further.
